title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to securities transactions with registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to securities transactions with registered investment companies. The amendment includes criteria for issuers to be deemed as investment companies based on the ownership of their outstanding securities by qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to securities transactions with registered investment companies. Issuers who are qualified purchasers will be deemed as investment companies for certain limitations on securities transactions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to securities transactions with registered investment companies. Issuers who are qualified purchasers will be deemed as investment companies for certain limitations on securities transactions. SEC. 4 defines a qualified purchaser. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person or entity meeting specific financial criteria for owning securities of non-affiliated issuers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a person or entity meeting specific financial criteria for owning securities of non-affiliated issuers, based on factors such as financial sophistication, net worth, assets owned, and relationship with an issuer. The Investment Company Act of 1940 defines a "qualified purchaser" based on financial criteria such as net worth, assets owned, and relationship with an issuer. The Commission may adopt rules for these individuals as deemed necessary for investor protection. SEC. 5 amends the definition of investment securities under the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph stating that companies not issuing redeemable securities and regulated by the state can provide financial or managerial assistance for economic development in the state. The amendment allows companies regulated by the state to provide financial or managerial assistance for economic development in the state, with specific requirements for the sale of securities. The amendment allows companies in the state to sell securities only to accredited investors and prohibits the purchase of securities issued by investment companies. The amendment restricts the sale of securities to accredited investors and prohibits the purchase of securities issued by investment companies, except for certain exclusions. The amendment requires companies to invest 65 percent of their assets in specific securities or comparable quality securities. Companies must comply with certain provisions of the Investment Company Act and file a notification with the Commission to rely on this exemption. The amendment requires companies to invest a majority of their assets in specific securities and comply with provisions of the Investment Company Act. Companies must file a notification with the Commission to rely on the exemption provided in the paragraph. The exemption may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to change the exemption amount to $10,000,000 or as determined by the Commission. SEC. 8 defines an eligible portfolio company. SEC. 8 amends the definition of eligible portfolio company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 by setting limits on total assets and capital. SEC. 9 amends the definition of business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 to exclude the requirement of providing significant managerial assistance to certain types of companies. SEC. 10 addresses the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 regarding the acquisition of assets by business development companies. It allows for acquisitions from any person, subject to regulations set by the Commission. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The new requirement is set at 200 percent, but companies can have a coverage of not less than 110 percent under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. Companies must meet specific criteria including exceeding 120% of total income over expenses and having at least 50% of assets invested in specified securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. Companies must meet specific criteria including having at least 50% of assets invested in specified securities and prohibiting certain distributions on senior securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. It is unlawful for any business development company to declare dividends or distributions on capital stock without meeting specific criteria, including maintaining an asset coverage of at least 110 percent. Compliance with regulations is necessary to maintain status as a regulated investment company under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires business development companies to meet specific criteria, including maintaining asset coverage of at least 110 percent, to maintain their status as regulated investment companies under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It is unlawful for these companies to issue senior securities representing stock without provisions to restrict dividends or distributions on common stock. The Investment Company Act of 1940 mandates that business development companies must have at least 110 percent asset coverage to remain regulated investment companies under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. They are prohibited from issuing senior securities without restrictions on dividends or distributions on common stock. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires business development companies to maintain 110 percent asset coverage to be regulated investment companies under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Prohibited from issuing senior securities without restrictions on dividends or distributions on common stock. The Investment Company Act of 1940 mandates that business development companies must have 110 percent asset coverage to be regulated investment companies under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. They are not allowed to issue senior securities without limitations on dividends or distributions on common stock. Additionally, a business development company can issue warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to, convert to, or purchase voting securities not accompanied by securities, subject to certain conditions and shareholder or partner approval. The proposal to issue warrants, options, or rights by a business development company must be authorized by shareholders or partners and approved by the required majority of directors or general partners. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include "and capital structure" after "portfolio".
